results.title: Exercise Musk-ox
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Robert Anderson, Douglas Wilkinson and E Scythes
results.brief_description: A journey of scientific exploration through Canada’s north. Members of the Canadian Army, with snowmobiles and amphibious weasel, made a great winter trek over country never before travelled by motor vehicle. The expedition took detailed weather observations, corrected maps, studied the mobility of snow vehicles, and coped with the weather. Through human skill and endurance the frontier of the north was pushed back, showing its rich promise for the future.

results.title: Exercise green!
results.creator_credit: Kingcroft Productions, Terry Ohlsson and Philip Bond
results.brief_description: A simulated full scale military, naval and air force assault exercise from planning through victualling, sappers’ engineering, parachuting and shelling followed by a computer analysis of the entire operation.

results.title: Exercise Beats Arthritis
results.brief_description: Regular exercise helps you to gain some control over your arthritis and take responsibility for yourself. Working with this video, you can begin to plan your own exercise program, building exercise and activity into your daily life. Learn how to relax too, so you can release built-up tension and calm your mind. Valerie Sayce is a physiotherapist who specialises in exercise programs for people with arthritis. She works at the Arthritis Foundation of Victoria as a Physical Activities educator.

results.title: Excursion to the bridge of friendship
results.brief_description: A sophisticated Sydney woman gets back to her cultural roots in this wonderful black and white musical tale of female bonding and Bulgarian folk singers. Christina Andreef packs this joyful short with plenty of spirit as it briskly reinvents and updates the classic Hollywood movie musical maxim of ‘putting on a show’.

results.title: Excursion to the bridge of friendship
results.creator_credit: Puss Puss Productions, Australian Film Commission, New South Wales Film and Television Office, Helen Bowden and Christina Andreef
results.brief_description: A sophisticated Sydney woman answers a letter from a famous Bulgarian folksinger she doesn’t know in an attempt to build the bridge that will allow a “singing Slav” to break the inner city market of Sydney. A very funny “silent musical”. No dialogue, English subtitles and musical soundtrack.

results.title: Excretory system
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Human Body”.
Part of a series which comprehensively covers the nine major systems of the body. This episode examines the functions of the excretory system. Diagrammatic animation clarifiers the role of the blood as transporters of wastes away from the cells and the work of the lungs, kidneys and skin as they remove carbon dioxide, water and heat, salts and nitrogen compounds.

results.title: Exchange rates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Economics”.
Richard Bluck of Melbourne College of Advanced Education provides an overview of exchange rates. Highlights the background of the current ‘floating of the dollar’ showing alternatives and implications of the decision. Addresses fixed or floating exchange rates, definitions and mechanisms, problems of floating exchange rates, implications for public policy and management of the economy and the Australian experience.

results.title: Exchange place
results.creator_credit: Texture Films, Marc De Rossi and Gary Gasgarth
results.brief_description: A story told in mime. Rich man, beggar, thief, shoeshine boy and waiter are linked in this original and ironic tale. All parts are played by the mime, Don Jordan and using masks and body movement, he projects each character not only as a distinct personality, but also as an unforgettable social type.

results.title: Exchange and divide
results.creator_credit: BFI, Donna Grey and Margaret Dickinson
results.brief_description: Kenneth Carr, a young executive in a multinational company, is facing the prospect of divorce. The audience is invited to become involved with him and to participate in a story centred around his emotional and sexual life. This expectation is frustrated when Kenneth’s solicitor jumps out of his fictional role and, adopting the manner of a neutral, authoritative expert, invites the audience instead to absorb useful facts. These are mainly to do with family law and finance; the Carr’s marriage is treated as convenient case history. The solicitor’s account is supplemented by various images and by short interventions from people connected with the couple. These are introduced as if their purpose was illustrative but rather than reinforce his words, they begin to contradict them and to offer alternative interpretations. Through the couple, interest is focused on the complexities of a hierarchy determined both by class and sex.
